bodyText: Little Falls Branch drains from Maryland and Washington DC and flows under C&O Canal into the Potomac River at Little Falls rapids. The rapids mark the upstream end of the tidal Potomac. In the 1800's, a dam diverted water from the stream into the reservoirs that supplied the District Of Columbia with water. When the Washington Aqueduct was built, the dams were removed. Streams like the Little Falls Branch, flow under the canal through culverts. There are approximately 180 culverts along the 184.5 miles of canal.
audioDescription:
(123 words)
Little Falls Branch is located along the western side of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Towpath, about eight-tens of a mile north of Chain Bridge Road.
From C&O Canal Lock 5, travel south on the C&O Canal Towpath about four hundred eighty yards. The canal flows parallel to the towpath on its eastern side. To the west a creek flows away from the canal and towpath, through lush forest towards the Potomac River.
A dirt trail runs alongside the creek on its south side. About twenty feet down the trail, a tunnel is visible back to the east which allows the water to run under the towpath. The thin trail continues west through the woods and toward the Potomac River, through rocky terrain.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Lockkeeper's House
listingDescription: Where Constitution Avenue now runs, the Chesapeake and Ohio and Washington City Canals ran between 1832 and the 1870s. The lockkeeper was responsible for opening and closing the lock at the end of the C&O Canal and for collecting tolls. The Lockkeeper's House was converted to a visitor information station in 2018.

images.altText: A small two story brick bulding with two chimneys and four windows
images.caption: Lockkeeper's House

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: National Mall and Memorial Parks
relatedParks.name: National Mall and Memorial Parks

bodyText:
Where Constitution Avenue now runs, the Chesapeake and Ohio and Washington City Canals ran between 1832 and the 1870s. The lockkeeper was responsible for opening and closing the lock at the end of the C&O Canal and for collecting tolls. The Lockkeeper's House was moved and converted to a visitor information station in 2018.

Inscriptions

plaque
Lock Keeper's House
Formerly the Eastern Terminal of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal
Erected about 1835
The canal passed along the present line of B Street in front of this house emptying into Tiber Creek and the Potomac River
Office of Public Buildings and Public Parks
July 4, 1928
audioDescription:
(353 words)
The Lockkeeper's House is located at the southwest intersection of 17th street NW and Constitution avenue in Washington, DC
The house is a one and one half-story building, thirty feet wide and eight feet deep. It is constructed of field stone with a shingled roof and stone chimney at either side of the structure. The central wood front door faces Constitution avenue and is flanked by two windows directly below two dormers in the roof. The facade is repeated in the back along with black metal railings that lead up to both front and back doors. There are no windows on either side of the building.
To the left of the front door is a one by one-and-one-half foot bronze plaque that reads:
Lock Keeper's House
Formerly the Eastern Terminal of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal
Erected about 1835
The canal passed along the present line of B Street in front of this house emptying into Tiber Creek and the Potomac River
Office of Public Buildings and Public Parks
July 4, 1928
A ten-foot long walkway leads from the sidewalk to the front door. A two-foot tall stone wall lines the front of the house, spanning about forty feet to the left and sixty feet to the right. Plantings are set at the left front of the building and a lawn runs to the right about eighty feet.
The back of the house features a fifty-foot wide, seventy-five-foot long stone plaza area. Set at the south end is a fifteen-foot wide brown cement structure, about three feet tall with three rounded step-like curves at the front, between two columns. The south and east sides of the plaza are lined with a two-foot tall stone wall, separated by a twenty-foot wide opening on the east side. Engraved on the left edge of the wall at the opening is:
Constitution Gardens
The same inscription is also along the wall at the left corner on the Constitution Avenue side.
A rectangular garden area is set at the southeast corner of the plaza and a circular garden, about ten-feet-wide sits in the northeast corner of the space.
END OF DESCRIPTION

bodyText: Low Water Intake on the C&O Canal
audioDescription:
(377 words)
The Low water intake is accessed from a path off the C&O Canal towpath in Washington, D.C. Travel north about four-tens of a mile on the towpath from the Chain Bridge overpass. A gravel path will be on the left. Just north along the left side of the towpath, will be two red and white signs.
The sign on the left is about three by three feet tall and written across a red border in white letters reads: "Danger." Below on a white panel, with translations in Spanish and Vietnamese reads:
Extremely strong current/undertow
Stay off rocks at river's edge
No swimming or wading
The right sign reads in red letters, with Spanish translation below:
Trash Free Park
The gravel trail becomes a twenty-foot wide cement paved road after about ten feet and descends slightly into the forest. At about one hundred yards large jagged boulders begin to line the left side of the trail. Twenty feet further there is a ten-foot tall stone and rock wall that lines the right side as well. Low water, about one-inch deep flows slowly on the path to the west towards the Potomac River.
Continuing west, the tall forest trees lessen. The path stays in a straight line and becomes more open, though still lined by rock on both sides. Some trees and vegetation hang over the high rock sides.
After about two hundred yards into the path, it turns to the right and rises slightly up a five-foot ramp into a cement plaza area. The cement runs about one hundred feet north to south and eighty feet east to west. At the south west corner of the plaza are four cement steps with cement railings on both sides that lead to another platform area.
The twenty by forty-foot rectangular space is surrounded by a three-foot high, one-foot thick cement wall. It sits along the east edge of the Potomac River as water rushes by from right to left. A ten-foot buffer of rock and large boulders lines the area between the plaza and river.
Lush forest trees fill the western hillside across the river and three large mansions sit along the top. To the south about three hundred yards along the river the Chain Bridge spans east to west.
END OF DESCRIPTION

images.altText: Elevated view of Harpers Ferry, two rivers, and two railroad bridges.
images.title: Maryland Heights
images.caption: Maryland Heights is the highest mountain overlooking Harpers Ferry.

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Harpers Ferry National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Harpers Ferry

bodyText:
The majority of hikers ascend Maryland Heights in search of a good view or a healthy workout. This mountain offers both hikes and scenic overlooks which will not disappoint. If history is your thing, Maryland Heights has remnants of extensive Civil War campsites and fortifications and its elevation made it hugely important during the war. To access this area, walk from Lower Town across the footbridge over the Potomac River to the C&O Canal towpath then take a left and walk along the path until there is signage for the Maryland Heights trail.

Maryland Heights is the highest mountain overlooking Harpers Ferry. Its southern face is a 300-foot vertical cliff that towers over the Potomac River, the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad, and the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. The mountain is steep, rugged, and primitive, with a thick veneer of Civil War history.

Maryland Heights hosted the first battle between Union and Confederate troops in Maryland. The first combat on Northern soil between the two armies occurred on Maryland Heights. Maryland Heights was the most important strategic target of the Confederate army in the Battle of Harpers Ferry, which took place from September 12-15, 1862. Without the seizure of Maryland Heights, Robert E. Lee's Confederates could not entrap the Union garrison and complete Lee's assignment outlined in Special Orders 191.

Lee selected Maj. Gen. Lafayette McLaws to lead the advance upon Maryland Heights, expecting McLaws to snare the Union garrison from the north. McLaws arrived at the eastern base of the mountain on September 12 with 8,000 men. Discovering nearly 4,000 Union soldiers stationed atop the mountain, McLaws directed William Barksdale's Mississippi brigade and Joseph Kershaw's South Carolina brigade to ascend Elk Ridge north of Maryland Heights and to take the Union position. Battling at Maryland Heights lasted from 6:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. on September 13, and eventually, the Union troops under Colonel Thomas H. Ford's command abandoned their position. The loss of Maryland Heights cut off the Union forces escape routes and helped lead to the surrender of the Union garrison on September 15.

The significance of Maryland Heights is further attested by the Union occupation of the mountain two days following the Battle of Antietam. By securing the heights on September 19, the Union, once again, occupied Harpers Ferry and to ensure the protection of the position, Maj. Gen. George B. McClellan ordered that extensive fortifications be constructed on Maryland Heights. Union engineers quickly surveyed the terrain, and during the fall of 1862, work commenced on the Stone Fort and the 30-pounder Battery, along with improvements at the Naval Battery. Ten months later, as General Lee threatened Harpers Ferry with his second invasion during the Gettysburg Campaign; construction hastened which resulted in the Interior Fort, the Exterior Fort, and the 100-pounder Battery. This latter battery boasted a 100-pounder Parrott Rifle that could hurl a 100-pound shell more than two miles and the tube of this cannon weighed nearly 10 tons.

The fortifications of Maryland Heights played a major role in the Confederacy's third and final invasion of the North. Confederate Maj. Gen. Jubal Early spent four days attempting to maneuver the Union out of the forts, but he failed. During the time Early spent worrying about Maryland Heights, the Union was able to send reinforcements to Washington, ultimately helping to save the United States capital. The Union army would occupy the forts of Maryland Heights until June 30, 1865. The final time the big cannon boomed was in memory of President Lincoln following his assassination.

Though Maryland Heights was occupied by Union forces the most, Maryland Heights occupation was by Confederates. Col. Thomas Jonathan Jackson seized the mountain in May 1861. Recognizing the strategic value of the high ground, Jackson was sure he could not defend Harpers Ferry without holding Maryland Heights. Jackson's aggressiveness created major turmoil when he positioned his troops in neutral Maryland, a state that the Confederacy was trying to get to join their cause. Despite the political firestorm set off by Jackson, he refused to abandon the position. The Confederates left on their own volition on June 14, 1861, when the Confederates abandoned Harpers Ferry five weeks before the First Battle of Manassas (Bull Run).
audioDescription: Summit of a rocky ridge covered in cliff faces. The overlook offers a birds-eye view of the town of Harpers Ferry and the two rivers that surround it, the Shenandoah and Potomac.

title: Monocacy Aqueduct
listingDescription: The glistening white and pink quartz sandstone structure is the longest aqueduct along the C&O Canal measuring 516 feet.

images.altText: A blue and orange sky over the aqueduct.
images.title: Monocacy Aqueduct
images.caption: The aqueduct allows boats to pass over the river below.

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail
relatedParks.name: Potomac Heritage

bodyText: The C&O Canal aqueducts are “water bridges” that carried canal boats over the creeks and rivers that flow into the Potomac River. Built from 1829 to 1833, the Monocacy Aqueduct is the third of twelve such “works of art” on the canal. With just one glace, visitors are struck with the magnitude of this marvelous seven arched structure. The glistening white and pink quartz sandstone structure is the longest aqueduct along the C&O Canal measuring in at 516 feet. At the time of the Civil War, during the Maryland Campaign of 1862, the Monocacy Aqueduct was nearly destroyed by Confederate General D.H. Hill. However, concerned Lockkeeper Thomas Walter persuaded the Confederate troops that destroying Lock 27 would be far more impactful in their pursuit. Today, the Monocacy Aqueduct still stands thanks to restoration work that was completed in 2004 and continual preservation of this structural gem.
audioDescription: (337 words) The Monocacy Aqueduct is located along the C&O Canal Towpath in Dickerson, Maryland. This granite stone bridge is 516 feet long and spans the Monocacy River. It has seven arches and each arch spans a distance of approximately 54 feet. The base of the arches, called piers, are six feet wide. There are six piers. The top of the aqueduct has a water way for the canal boats and a towpath for the mules. The waterway of the aqueduct is about 20 feet wide and its bottom is about six feet lower than the towpath. The walls on either side of the aqueduct are about 8 feet wide. To get to the aqueduct start from the Monocacy Aqueduct Parking Lot. From the parking lot head back toward the road you drove in on, near the northern edge of the lot. Once back on the road, head northwest about 100 feet toward the gravel access path. The path forks about 60 feet down the access path. To the right is a path that leads to picnic tables and a scenic view of the aqueduct. To the left the access path continues to the towpath. Continue down the access path on the left another 220 feet. The access path will dead end into the towpath. Once on the towpath turn right toward the aqueduct. About 200 feet down the towpath is a fork in the path. To the right is access to the aqueduct waterway. To the left is access to the aqueduct towpath. The waterway sits about six feet lower than the towpath. Select a path and walk another 200 feet to the aqueduct. On the waterway path you can see stone blocks forming walls on either side of you that are about 6 feet tall. On the towpath you can look down into the waterway on your right or look to the left were the Monocacy River meets the Potomac River. The towpath has a fence on the river side and two-foot bumpers on the waterway side.

title: Old Stone House
listingDescription: Georgetown's Old Stone House is the oldest building on its original foundation in the District of Columbia, predating the establishment of the District itself.

images.altText: A man stands in front of the Old Stone House circa 1900.
images.caption: The Old Stone House, built in 1766, is the oldest structure on its original foundation in D.C.

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Rock Creek Park
relatedParks.name: Rock Creek

bodyText:
The Old Stone House is the oldest structure on its original foundation in Washington, D.C. Built in 1766 in the British colony of Maryland, the house was already 59 years old when the British invaded Washington, D.C. in 1814. Although it is preserved for its architecture today, it was originally preserved through a case of mistaken identity and a desire to remember George Washington.

In 1791, George Washington and city planner Pierre L'Enfant were surveying the newly established District of Columbia. L'Enfant's ambitious plan for the city's layout depended on negotiating with local landowners for right of way. During one of these meetings, Washington and L'Enfant stayed in Georgetown's Fountain Inn at 31st and K Streets. The inn was better known to locals as Suter's Tavern, after its owner John Suter. 

Over on Bridge Street (now M Street), John Suter's son, John, Jr., ran a clock shop in today's Old Stone House. As the years passed, local memory conflated the two buildings associated with the two John Suters. Thus, the desire to honor and remember George Washington's 1791 visit combined with a fuzzy memory led to the Old Stone House's preservation while so much changed around it.

The house was the site of a car dealership when the federal government purchased the property in 1953. The National Park Service opened the house to the public in 1960. Today, the house is a rare example of pre-Revolutionary architecture. Among the House's furnishings, you may find a clock built by one-time owner John Suter, Jr.

Hours:

Open daily (ground floor only), with holiday hours from 11:00 a.m.-7:00 p.m.

title: Olmsted Island and Overlook Trail

images.altText: Brown 'stay on boardwalk' sign with boardwalk in distance
images.title: Olmsted Island boardwalk
images.caption: NPS Photo

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail
relatedParks.name: Potomac Heritage

bodyText:
A series of boardwalks and bridges traverse a unique floodplain terrace environment and lead to the Great Falls Overlook. The overlook provides spectacular views of the Great Falls, as the Potomac River drops over 60 feet and continues through the Mather Gorge.

Trail is 1/4 mile in length (one way) from trailhead to overlook. Stay on the boardwalk. Dogs are not permitted. Boardwalk is handicap accessible.
audioDescription: (104 words) From the Great Falls Tavern Visitor Center parking lot, follow the sidewalks to the visitor center, passing the concessions building on your right and the public restrooms building on your left. At the visitor center building, turn right, walk about 25 feet and cross the wooden pedestrian bridge over Lock 20. Turn left and walk 1/2 of a mile on the towpath to the trailhead, on your right. Trail is a series of boardwalks and bridges, crossing river channels and the Olmsted Island. Trail is a quarter mile long, with railings on both sides the entire way, and then arrives at Great Falls Overlook.

title: Paw Paw Tunnel

images.altText: The mouth a Paw Paw Tunnel built into a rock wall.
images.title: Paw Paw Tunnel
images.caption: Paw Paw Tunnel

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail
relatedParks.name: Potomac Heritage

bodyText:
The Paw Paw Tunnel is one of the most significant engineering features on the Canal. To save building six miles of canal along the river, the C&O Canal Company decided to construct a tunnel through a steep topographic ridge now called Tunnel Hill. When work began on the tunnel in 1836, the builders estimated the project would be completed within two years. The tunnel ultimately required 14 years to complete due to labor issues and violence, funding shortfalls, work stoppages, and the challenges of digging a 3,118-foot tunnel through the hard, loose shale. The tunnel opened in October 1850 with rockslides continuing to be a challenge throughout the tunnel’s history. 

Today, when you plan your visit to the Paw Paw Tunnel, bring a flashlight and discover the weep holes, rope burns, rub rails, as well as brass plates marking every 100-feet that bring the tunnel’s history to life. Following your travels through the tunnel, enjoy the two-mile long Tunnel Hill Trail where you can discover breathtaking views of the Paw Paw Bends.
audioDescription: (142 words) Paw Paw Tunnel is located along the towpath in Oldtown, Maryland. To access it, go to the Paw Paw Tunnel Drive-in Campground parking area off of MD-51. From the parking lot is a short, 50-foot path, with a slight incline that leads up to the towpath. Once on the gravel towpath, turn right and at about a half a mile, you will approach Paw Paw Tunnel. It is 3,118 feet long with wooden railings on the left side and the wall of the tunnel on the right. The tunnel contains the original railings and contain rope burns from when the canal boats were being pulled through the tunnel by mules. Along the wall are circular, brass plates that mark every 100 feet. At the downstream exit of the tunnel is a wooden boardwalk with railings on the left side. End of description.

title: Potomac Aqueduct
listingDescription: From 1843 to 1886, coal boats navigated across the Potomac Aqueduct - actually over the Potomac - on their way via the Alexandria Canal to the wharves of Alexandria, about 7 miles south of here. Later, the aqueduct became part of a trolley line from Rosslyn to Georgetown. If you look across the river, you can still see the only remaining pier.

images.title: The Aqueduct along the C&O Canal
images.caption: The Aqueduct along the C&O Canal in Georgetown

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail
relatedParks.name: Potomac Heritage

bodyText: From 1843 to 1886, coal boats navigated across the Potomac Aqueduct - actually over the Potomac - on their way via the Alexandria Canal to the wharves of Alexandria, about 7 miles south of here. Later, the aqueduct became part of a trolley line from Rosslyn to Georgetown. If you look across the river, you can still see the only remaining pier.
audioDescription:
(191 words)
The Alexandria Aqueduct, also called the Potomac Aqueduct, is located just south of the C&O Canal Towpath in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC.
Travel west along the towpath about four hundred feet from the Key Bridge. Turn left and proceed south about one hundred seventy feet and you will be at the top of the aqueduct.
Facing south from this location an open grass and dirt field about one hundred feet wide and sixty feet long leads up to a chain link fence. Beyond the fence is the granite aqueduct structure, two, two hundred-foot spans of bridge about thirty feet apart. In between them is a grass surface about six feet below the top of the bridge spans, which stretches out about fifty feet.
Stairs about seventy feet to the west lead down to Water Street and the lower level of the aqueduct. Two arches of the aqueduct, about fifty feet wide each and constructed with granite blocks, are visible underneath. One carries over the end of Water Street and the trailhead of the Crescent Trail to the west. The second arch runs to the edge of the Potomac River.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Railroad Lift Bridge

images.altText: Railroad Lift Bridge
images.title: Railroad Lift Bridge
images.caption: Railroad Lift Bridge

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: Built in 1923 by the Western Maryland Railway, the railroad lift bridge is one of several one-of-a-kind features on the C&O Canal. Operating like an elevator, this structure lifted the railroad tracks to allow canal boats to pass beneath. The tracks, for transporting coal, led to the power plant between the river and the canal. In 1924, the C&O Canal closed making the lift bridge unnecessary. The bridge was lifted in 2016 to allow boats to pass underneath, and in 2019 a wooden staircase was installed to allow visitors to cross the bridge to reach the towpath.
audioDescription: The railroad lift bridge is located on the towpath in Williamsport Maryland. To get to the lift bridge start at the Cushwa Basin Visitor Center parking lot. From the parking lot, head to the southern most point of the lot to reach the towpath access path. Once on the access path, walk about 20 feet to reach the staircase at the base of the lift bridge. There are wooden railings on both sides of the staircase. You can see rail road tracks to the left of the staircase. The bridge spans upward and downward, forming a metal cage like structure. Atop the bridge, you can see the Bollman Bridge crossing the canal on the left. On the right, you can see the bridge into West Virginia crossing over the towpath. Past this bridge, you can see the towpath stretching toward the Conocogue Aqueduct. The bridge is about 35 feet long, and ends at a stairwell that turns to the right. Wooden railings are on both sides of the stairs. The end of the staircase points you Northwest onto the towpath, towards the Conocogue Aqueduct.

title: Seneca Aqueduct

images.altText: A single arch aqueduct spans a creek.
images.title: Seneca Aqueduct
images.caption: Seneca Aqueduct

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: The C&O Canal aqueducts were water filled bridges that once carried canal boats over the creeks and rivers that flow into the Potomac. Here, the Seneca Aqueduct and Lock 24 are combined into a single structure. The only place along the canal were this was necessary. The aqueduct and lock are made of Seneca red sandstone quarried just west of here. That same sandstone was used to build the Smithsonian Castle in Washington, DC. Construction of the aqueduct and lock was completed in 1832 at a cost of $32,000.
audioDescription: (292 words) Seneca Aqueduct is located along the towpath near Poolesville, Maryland. It can be accessed from a small parking lot located at the end of Riley’s Lock Road. Head to the Southwest corner of the lot to were a small access path takes you to the towpath. Walk about 75 feet and turn right onto the towpath. While on the access path you will walk up a set of stairs and a wooden foot bridge which crosses over lock 24. The staircase has a railing on the right side. The wooden foot bridge has railing on both sides. If you look to the right while on the towpath you can see lock 24 merging into the Seneca aqueduct. The lock portion of the canal is about 15 feet deep. At the location were the lock and aqueduct join, the canal bottom steps up about 10 feet. Walk about 15 feet to reach the aqueduct. On top of the aqueduct, you will be on the towpath looking down into the waterway on your right, which is about 5 feet deep here. There is no barrier between the towpath and the drop into the canal. Looking to the right, you can see the far canal wall and Seneca creek. On your left, is a metal fence and a view of the creek joining the Potomac River. A head of you, on the aqueduct, part of the structure has fallen away. You can see metal beams bridging the gap that was left when it fell apart. A wooden foot bridge, directly in front of you, will carry you over this gap and the creek. The bridge has wooden railing on both sides. Looking down while on the bridge will give you a view of the creek.

title: Sideling Hill Creek Aqueduct

images.altText: A single arch aqueduct spans a creek.
images.title: Sideling Hill Creek Aqueduct
images.caption: Sideling Hill Creek Aqueduct

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: The C&O Canal aqueducts are “water bridges” that once carried canal boats over the creeks and rivers that flow into the Potomac. The Sideling Hill Creek Aqueduct, built between 1837 and 1840, is the ninth of twelve such “works of art” on the canal. The 70-foot long structure spans the Sideling Hill Creek, which marks the boundary between Washington and Allegany County.
audioDescription: (230 words) The Sideling Hill Creek Aqueduct is located along the towpath in Hancock, Maryland. It has a single, 75-foot-long arch. The top of the aqueduct has two parts, a water way that once canal boats and a towpath for mules. The waterway of the aqueduct is about 20 feet wide and had two walls, which created a six-foot-deep canal. Atop the southern wall is the towpath mules use to travel on. To get to the aqueduct start from the Lock 56 parking lot. Head to the Southwest corner of the lot to reach an access trail to the towpath. Walk about 80 feet on the access trail and then turn right (west) onto the towpath. Walk 6 tenths of a mile to the aqueduct. Once on the aqueduct, you will be walking in the canal waterway. On your left, the wall that makes the side of the waterway sits about six feet tall. On top of this wall is the original towpath. A metal fence sits on top of the wall, on the far side towpath, between the towpath and the drop to the creek. On the right, the canal wall no longer exists, giving an unobstructed view of Sideling Creek. In the distance a metal bridge crosses the creek. You can also see concrete and metal bracers stabilizing the aqueduct. There is no barrier between the path and the drop.

title: Thompson Boat Center
listingDescription: Boat rentals and lessons on the Potomac River

images.altText: A two story structure with four garage doors on the ground level. Boats are stacked on dock
images.title: Thompson Boat Center
images.caption: Thompson Boat Center on the Potomac River

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail
relatedParks.name: Potomac Heritage

relatedParks.fullName: Rock Creek Park
relatedParks.name: Rock Creek

bodyText:
Thompson Boat Center sits on the Potomac River near the intersection of the Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway and Virginia Avenue. The boathouse provides rentals of canoes, kayaks and other non-motorized watercraft.  

Information on rentals and lessons are available on the Boating in DC website.

Please note, there is a fee for parking in the parking lot at the Thompson Boat Center.
audioDescription: Thompson Boat Center sits on the Potomac River near the intersection of the Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway and Virginia Avenue. The boathouse sits between the tidal lock for the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal and the Potomac River. The boat dock angles away from the front of the building and leads to edge of the water. Canoes, kayaks and other watercraft are stacked along the docks and in the boat house garages.

title: Tonoloway Aqueduct

images.altText: A single arch aqueduct spans a creek.
images.title: Tonoloway Aqueduct
images.caption: Tonoloway Aqueduct

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: The C&O Canal aqueducts are “water bridges” that once carried canal boats over the creeks and rivers that flow into the Potomac. The Tonoloway Aqueduct, built between 1835 and 1839, is the eighth of twelve such “works of art” on the canal.
audioDescription: (196 words) The Tonoloway Aqueduct is located along the towpath in Hancock, Maryland. It has a single, 80-foot long arch. The top of the aqueduct has two parts, a water way for canal boats and a towpath for mules. The waterway of the aqueduct is about 25 feet wide and had two walls, which created a five-foot-deep canal. Atop the southern wall is the towpath. To get to Tonoloway Aqueduct, start at lock 52. From Lock 52, walk west on the towpath for about 150 feet to the aqueduct. While walking between lock 52 and the aqueduct, you will notice that the canal, on the right, drops down about 5 feet. There is no barrier between the towpath and this drop. Once on the aqueduct, a metal fence will appear on the left of the towpath. This will eventually change to a wooden railing on both sides of the towpath. On top of the aqueduct, you will be on the towpath looking down into the waterway on your right. Part of the far canal wall has fallen away, leaving an unobstructed view of Tonoloway creek. On your left, you can see Tonoloway Creek merging into the Potomac River.

title: Town Creek Aqueduct

images.altText: A single arch aqueduct spans a creek.
images.title: Town Creek Aqueduct
images.caption: Town Creek Aqueduct

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: The C&O Canal aqueducts are “water bridges” that once carried canal boats over the creeks and rivers that flow into the Potomac. The Town Creek Aqueduct is the eleventh of twelve such “works of art” on the canal. Construction began in 1837 and was abandoned in 1838 during the Canal company’s financial crisis. It was completed during the final phase of canal construction (1848-1850) by Michael Byrne.
audioDescription: (157 words) Town Creek Aqueduct is located along the towpath in Oldtown, Maryland. To access it, go to the Town Creek Aqueduct parking area. In the parking lot, head to the South West corner of the lot where a small access trail will lead you to the towpath. Walk about 30 feet on the access path and turn right (West) onto the towpath. Walk about 80 feet on the towpath to reach the aqueduct. Once on the aqueduct, you will be walking in the canal waterway. On your left, the wall that makes the side of the waterway sits about 4 feet tall. On top of this wall is the original towpath. A metal fence sits on the far side of this original towpath, between the towpath and the drop to the creek. On the right, the canal wall no longer exists, giving an unobstructed view of Town Creek. There is no barrier between the path and the drop.

title: Washington Aqueduct
listingDescription: The construction and successful operation of the Washington Aqueduct epitomizes the Army Corps of Engineers entry into the field of public works and reflects the military influence on civil life in antebellum America. The Washington Aqueduct, constructed over 150 years ago, still supplies the nation's capital with public water today.

images.altText: Union Bridge in the distance circa 1863. Two people in the foreground looking at camera.
images.caption: Union Bridge, circa 1863 (Library of Congress)

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail
relatedParks.name: Potomac Heritage

bodyText:
The Washington Aqueduct was the District of Columbia's first public water system. Built by the Army Corps of Engineers from 1853 to 1863, it was a monumental engineering achievement. Its designer, Army Engineer Montgomery C. Meigs, supervised the project until 1861, when he was appointed Quartermaster General of the U.S. Army. The construction and successful operation of the Washington Aqueduct symbolizes the Army Corps of Engineers importance in the field of public works and reflects the military influence on life in antebellum America. The Washington Aqueduct, constructed over 150 years ago, still supplies the nation's capital with public water today.

In the 1850s, the growing population of Washington and the memory of two devastating fires forced Congress to acknowledge that the nation's capital required more than wells and springs to provide its water. In 1853, Congress commissioned a public water system. One year later, construction of the Washington Aqueduct began in Great Falls, Maryland. Meig's plan was to divert the water from the Potomac River into a large, underground conduit. Gravity, and later pumping stations, directed water through the conduit to reservoirs where it could then be pumped into the city's pipelines.

To accomplish this feat, the Army Corps of Engineers constructed a masonry dam across the Potomac, a control gatehouse at Great Falls, a twelve-mile conduit, eleven tunnels, six bridges, several pipelines, and two reservoirs. By 1863, the Corps had completed three resevoirs. Wagons and boats on the C&O Canal brought supplies like cast iron, sand, concrete, brick, and Seneca sandstone to the construction sites. The initial dam reached halfway across the river. In 1890, in order to meet the District's increasing demand for water, it was extended to the Virginia side. Meigs designed the dam to be anchored to the river bottom, not to block its flow but to divert it.

Although no longer in service, the first gatehouse still stands next to the historic Great Falls Tavern along the C&O Canal in Maryland. Inside was a system of 20 small cast iron slide gates that filtered the largest debris from the water.

The conduit stretches almost twelve miles downriver from the intake at Great Falls to the Georgetown Reservoir. The underground, circular tube, built of brick, stone, and mortar, is 9 feet in diameter. A road ran parallel to the conduit to facilitate cleaning, repairs and inspections. The road was originally named Conduit Road; today it is MacArthur Boulevard.

As part of the original Washington Aqueduct water system, workers constructed six bridges to carry the conduit over streams and creeks. Only three, Bridge #3, Cabin John Bridge (also called Union Arch Bridge) and Rock Creek Bridge, remain today. Cabin John Bridge, built of granite and sandstone, held the record as the world's longest masonry arch structure (220 feet) for 40 years. Today, Rock Creek Bridge’s 200-foot arch is still one of the longest unsupported metal pipe arches in the world. 

Aqueduct water spilled into two reservoirs, Dalecarlia Reservoir at the District line and the Georgetown Reservoir two miles downriver. By allowing the murky river water to stand in these reservoirs, debris settles to the bottom before distribution throughout the city. However, the process never successfully removed all of the sediment and thus, Washington City's public water had a muddy-yellowish color until the installation of a rapid-sand filtration system in 1928. Today both reservoirs have been completely modernized.

Several inscriptions at various places honor the engineers who designed and built the Aqueduct. Meigs had his own name and his assistant’s name, Alfred L. Rives, engraved on the Cabin John Bridge. When Rives quit the US Army to join the Confederate Army in 1861, Meigs replaced his name with the Latin phrase Esto Perpetua, or “Let It Stand Forever." After former US Secretary of War Jefferson Davis became the president of the Confederacy, his name was removed from the bridge as well. In 1909, Theodore Roosevelt ordered it be re-engraved.

While building the Washington Aqueduct, Meigs was also Chief Engineer for the extensions and new dome of the U.S. Capitol, and the enlargement of the General Post Office Building. Both of these buildings are now National Historic Landmarks. After his work with the new aqueduct, Meigs served as Quartermaster General of the United States Army, both during and after the Civil War. During this tenure, he designed the Pension Bureau building, now the National Building Museum (also a National Historic Landmark). During the Civil War, Meigs helped establish Arlington National Cemetery, where he is buried.

In the twentieth century, the aqueduct’s capacity was expanded many times. As of 2017, it produces 300 million gallons of filtered water per day, has a storage capacity of 44 million gallons, and serves 1.1 million customers. The aqueduct provides public water for all of Washington, DC, Arlington County, and Falls Church City in Virginia. The continual effectiveness of the historic water system is a testament to Meig’s design and the professional work of the Army Corps of Engineers who continue to operate it today. A portion of the aqueduct runs through the Cheasapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park, where you can see the originial engineer's house and gatehouse. 

 

Sources:
"The Washington Aqueduct System." National Park Service.
 

Ways, Harry C. Washinton Aqueduct: 1852-1992. US Army Corps of Engineers.

 

 

National Historic Landmark Nomination of the Washington Aqueduct.
 

National Historic Landmarks (NHLs) are historic places that possess exceptional value in commemorating or illustrating the history of the United States. The National Park Service’s National Historic Landmarks Program oversees the designation of such sites. There are just over 2,500 National Historic Landmarks. All NHLs are also listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Wisconsin Avenue bridge
listingDescription: This is the oldest masonry bridge in Washington, DC. It predates the incorporation of Georgetown into Washington, DC. Note the name on the eastside keystone - O(rville). B. Dibble - the engineer of the Wisconsin Ave. Bridge. Note also the name of Andrew Jackson - engraved on a stone plaque - who dedicated this bridge upon its completion in 1828. The bridge allowed traffic to cross the canal.
